foreignObject.div: üåê Modern Understanding: Crucial for understanding ancient civilizations.
Archaeological Impact: Translation of millions of clay tablets.
Key Discovery: The Behistun Inscription in Old Persian, Elamite, and Babylonian.
Decoding: Began in the 15th century, succeeded in the late 1700s.
üí° Impact: Extensive use in legal, religious, and scientific texts.
Astronomical Observations: MUL APIN, comprehensive astronomical tracking.
Religious Aspect: Divine skill for selected individuals.
Linguistic Roots: Foundation for modern languages.
üõ†Ô∏è Application: Included in the Law Code of Hammurabi, The Epic of Gilgamesh.
Purpose: Accounting, law, honor to gods.
Creation: Imprints on clay.
üåç Spread: Influenced phonetics of many Mesopotamian languages.
Beyond: Adapted by Elam in Persia, Ugarit, and Elba.
Primary Region: Mesopotamia.
üïí Significance: Basis for modern language inscriptions.
Decline: Replaced by the Phoenician alphabet.
Development: Evolved from pictographs to represent spoken language.
Origin: Traced back to ancient Sumer.
üë• Involvement: Key for temple records and law.
Professions: Used by Priests, Scribes, some women.
Sumerians: Originated in Sumer, spread to greater Mesopotamia.
üìú Cuneiform: "Wedge-shaped" writing.
Significance: Transitioned to bartering system with clay tokens.
Medium: Clay tablets with pictograms.
Description: Earliest form of literacy, used to track trades.
Extra Analysis: Decipherment and Legacy
Why: Cultural and Historical Significance
How: Method and Usage
Where: Geographical Spread
When: Historical Timeline
Who: Creators and Users
What: Ancient Writing System
